cards.rawTitle: What's the mood where you are?

item.title: Women's World Cup final: what's the mood where you are?
item.trailText: Japan take on the United States in the final in Vancouver on Sunday. We’re looking for fans of both sides, wherever they are in the world, to share their stories
item.standFirst: Japan take on the United States in the final in Vancouver on Sunday. We’re looking for fans of both sides, wherever they are in the world, to share their stories
item.body:
Japan, the current holders, and past winners the US are the finalists of the 2015 Women’s World Cup. They battle it out on Sunday evening in Vancouver, completing a tournament that has captured the public imagination around the world.

Who’s going to win? We have absolutely no idea. But that’s not why you’re here, we hope. Instead, we want to hear about the pre-final mood wherever you are, what the team you support means to you, and what you think will happen on Sunday.

Obviously, we’re particularly keen to hear from Japanese and American fans, whether they’re living in these respective countries or are living far from home. Or perhaps you’re an American living in Japan, or vice versa? But wherever you are, and wherever you’re from, if you’re following the final, we want to hear from you.

Share your photos and stories via GuardianWitness by pressing the blue button, or by filling in the form below. And may the best team win.

いよいよ今週日曜日に迫った女子ワールドカップ決勝戦に向け、ガーディアンでは日本とアメリカ両国のチームのファンからのストーリーを募集しています。是非、勝敗予想や期待のメッセージを写真と共に共有プラットフォームGuardian Witness、もしくは下記のフォームからシェアしてください。

cards.title: Ten years on from 7/7 / Share your memories

item.title: 7/7 10 years on: share your memories
item.trailText: Even if you weren’t directly affected by the shocking events of 7 July 2005, many will remember that day. Share your memories via GuardianWitness
item.standFirst: Even if you weren’t directly affected by the shocking events of 7 July 2005, many will remember that day. Share your memories via GuardianWitness
item.body:
It is now ten years since four bombs were detonated in London during rush hour, killing 52 and injuring more than 700. Even if you weren’t in London that day the scale and effect of the attacks had a huge impact across the UK.

Whether you were in London or elsewhere, we’d like to hear your memories of that day. How did you find out about the events? Did you follow the live news coverage? Were you personally affected by the attacks? Perhaps you were also in London that morning – or were anxious about relatives and friends? Was there any lasting impact?

Share your memories and stories and we’ll use the most interesting contributions in our reporting.

You can share your memories with GuardianWitness by clicking on the blue ‘Contribute’ buttons on this article. You can also use the GuardianWitness smartphone app or the Guardian app and search for ‘GuardianWitness assignments.’

item.body:
We’re now running a regular weekly photography assignment in the Observer New Review and the next theme is ‘note.’ So whether it’s a piece of music that you’re learning, a written reminder on your fridge or paying attention to something, share your photos of what note means to you – and tell us about your image in the description box.

The closing date is Thursday 9 July at 10 am. We’ll publish our favourites in The New Review on 12 July and in a gallery on the Guardian site.

You can share your ‘note’ pictures by clicking on the blue ‘Contribute’ button on this article. You can also use the GuardianWitness smartphone app or the Guardian app and search for ‘GuardianWitness assignments’ – and if you add it to the homepage – you can keep up with all our assignments.

cards.title: Liam Williams webchat at MIF / Post your questions now

item.title: Liam Williams webchat at MIF – post your questions now
item.trailText: Live from Manchester international festival, outsider comedian Liam Williams will be answering your questions on Monday 6 July from 2.15pm BST onwards – post them in the comments below
item.standFirst: Live from Manchester international festival, outsider comedian Liam Williams will be answering your questions on Monday 6 July from 2.15pm BST onwards – post them in the comments below

blocks.title: Post your questions for Liam Williams
blocks.body:
At the heart of Liam Williams’s comedy is the suspicion that everything is a bit rubbish, whether it’s pop culture, social inequality, or ultimately his own life. But he’s no insufferable sad-sack: his lacerations of himself and others reflect a desire to really feel and truly live.

This impassioned and very funny material, about anything from porn to mindfulness, won him a nomination as best newcomer at last year’s Edinburgh festival. He’s been around for a while though, with his surreal sketch trio Sheeps first hitting the fringe in 2010. He also played host at the recent comedy gigs in Parliament Square, held by the Occupy movement as part of their Festival of Democracy.

Next up is a stint at Manchester international festival alongside his peers from comedy venue The Invisible Dot, doing a nightly cabaret. He’ll join us live from the festival to answer your questions in a webchat, from 2.15pm onwards on Monday 6 July – post your questions in the comments below, and he’ll answer as many as possible.

item.body:
Do you and your pet like to travel? If so we’d like to hear from you. Perhaps you have a dog who loves to feel the wind in their hair like Uanín or enjoys a cheeky ice-cream when on a break. Wherever you are in the world, share your photos and videos with us. We’d also like to hear your tips on what makes a pet-friendly holiday.

We’ll feature the most interesting in a gallery on the site.

item.title: Do you have concerns about TTIP?
item.trailText: Some have never have heard of it, however the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership negotiations is fuelling a growing antipathy across Europe. Where do you stand on TTIP?
item.standFirst: Some have never have heard of it, however the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership negotiations is fuelling a growing antipathy across Europe. Where do you stand on TTIP?
item.body:
TTIP, the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership is a series of trade negotiations being carried out between the EU and US. The bilateral trade agreement deals with reducing regulatory barriers to big business trade: food safety law, environmental legislation, banking regulations and the sovereign powers of individual nations.

The aim of the talks is to turn the EU and US into the largest free-trade area in the world. However there are concerns that the negotiations, which have mostly been held in secret, could give too much power to private corporations and potentially undermine human rights.

Growing antipathy towards the talks has sparked protests in the UK and Europe, so we’d like to know where you stand on TTIP. Have you taken part in protests? What are your main concerns? Or do you you feel that fears are misplaced?

We’ll use the most interesting contributions in our reporting.

cards.rawTitle: Confused about what’s happening in Greece? - as it happened

item.title: Greek debt crisis Q&A – as it happened
item.trailText: Confused about what’s happening in Greece? Join financial editor Nils Pratley and feature writer Jon Henley for a live Q&A at 1pm BST
item.standFirst: Confused about what’s happening in Greece? Join financial editor Nils Pratley and feature writer Jon Henley for a live Q&A at 1pm BST
item.byline: Nils Pratley, Jon Henley, Guardian readers

displayImages.altText: A poster that reads "NO - at 5/6/2015 we are writing history" while on the background there are people in line waiting to withdraw money from an ATM in Athens, Greece.

blocks.body:
Greeks will vote in a referendum on Sunday to decide whether the country will accept the latest offer by creditors.

The result could have far-reaching consequences for the future of Greece and its place within the eurozone. Prime minister Alexis Tsiperas has remained defiant, insisting he will only agree to tough new austerity measures if Greece is granted debt relief. Meanwhile, the IMF yesterday announced Greece needs €50bn (£35bn or $55bn) of extra funds over the next three years and large-scale debt relief to stabilise the economy.

With so much happening, it can be difficult to keep track of events in Greece. At 1pm today, we’ll have feature writer Jon Henley, who has spent months in Greece reporting on the crisis and is currently in Athens, and financial editor Nils Pratley here answering your questions about the Greek crisis.

Post your questions in the comments below and we will publish the answers in the live blog as they come in.
Thanks for joining us for today’s Q&A. Nils and Jon have begun answering your questions below the line. We’ll be dragging their answers into the live blog as we go.
